slides.title: The Coffee Shop Question

content.headline: Which Coffee Shop Would You Choose?

scenario.option_a: The one with the best Facebook ads
scenario.option_b: The one your neighbor told you about

content.visual: Two coffee shops - one with ad banner, one with people chatting outside

slides.narration: Quick scenario. You're looking for a new coffee shop. You see an ad on Facebook for one—great photos, compelling copy. Your neighbor mentions another one—says they love it there. Which one do you try first? You already know the answer. Everyone does.

slides.title: Digital Marketing's Problem

content.headline: Digital Marketing = Shouting at Strangers
content.key_insight: People don't trust ads. They trust people.

slides.narration: Here's the problem with digital marketing: it's shouting at strangers. Average ad click-through rate? Point one percent. That means ninety-nine point nine percent of people ignore you. Eighty-six percent of people skip or actively block ads. Trust in advertising has dropped forty-two percent since 2020. You're spending money to yell at people who've learned to tune you out.

slides.title: Community Marketing

content.headline: Community Marketing = Being Part of Something

contrast.community: Be present where people already are

slides.narration: Community marketing is different. Instead of interrupting people with your message, you become part of where they already are. You're in the local directory they check. You're sponsoring the event they attend. You're mentioned in the news they read. Trust builds through presence, not persuasion. Relationships compound over time. Word-of-mouth scales. Loyalty lasts.

slides.title: The Trust Hierarchy

content.headline: Who People Trust (In Order)
content.insight: Community marketing operates in the top 3. Digital marketing operates in the bottom 2.

slides.narration: Look at who people trust. Ninety-two percent trust people they know personally. Seventy percent trust online reviews. Fifty-eight percent trust editorial content and news. Only thirty-three percent trust brand websites. And fourteen percent—fourteen—trust advertising. Community marketing operates in the top three. Digital marketing operates in the bottom two. That's the difference.

slides.title: Real Results Comparison

content.headline: Same Budget. Different Approach. Different Results.

slides.narration: Same budget, different approach, different results. Five hundred dollars on Facebook and Google ads gets you five thousand impressions, five clicks, maybe one conversion. And the moment you stop paying, you're invisible. Five hundred dollars on community presence—directory, events, news—gets you three thousand targeted local views, three hundred meaningful engagements, eight to twelve conversions on average. And it compounds. Your presence builds over time.

slides.title: The Restaurant That Stopped Advertising

content.headline: They Stopped Advertising. Sales Went Up.

case_study.decision: Stopped all ads. Invested in community presence.
actions: Got featured in local news twice
case_study.result: Sales up 23% in first year. Ad spend: $0.

slides.narration: Real story. A family restaurant, fifteen years in business. They were spending eight hundred a month on ads with declining returns. They made a decision: stop all advertising. Invest that money in community presence instead. They sponsored local events. Posted to the community calendar weekly. Got featured in local news twice. Engaged on the community platform. Result? Sales up twenty-three percent in the first year. Ad spend: zero.
